question: Is Egr3 required for maintaining the homeostasis of B and T lymphocytes? Answer with Yes or No.

content.source_1: Thus, Egr2 and Egr3 regulate B and T cell function in adaptive immune responses and homeostasis by promoting antigen receptor signaling and controlling inflammation.
content.source_2: In contrast to prior models, Egr2- and Egr3-deficient B and T cells maintained basal STAT1/STAT3 activity, and antigen receptor-triggered AP-1 activation was intact, indicating that Egr3 is dispensable for lymphocyte homeostasis.
content.source_3: Egr2 and/or Egr3 directly induce SOCS1 and SOCS3 and counteract the AP-1 inhibitor Batf in B and T cells, thereby constraining STAT1/STAT3 signaling and sustaining antigen receptor responses.
content.source_4: Conditional ablation of both Egr2 and Egr3 in mature lymphocytes did not affect antigen receptorâ€“induced proliferation of B or T cells and produced no systemic autoimmunity, consistent with preserved homeostatic control.
